The passage of Pliny3 “ Ex omnibus coloribus cretulam amant udoque illini recusant, purpurissimum, Indicum, caeruleum, meli- num, auripigmentum, appianum, cerussa,” applies to the process described by Vitruvius.

The phrase, however, os Theophilus “ in recenti muro'’ “ upon a new wall ’⁹ cannot be overlooked. It is not the ‘⁴ murus siccus” os chap. 15, but it appears to mean that ‘⁶ fresco” was intended by Theophilus. How then to coincide the neglect of our author in this instance with his universal care in description, if “ fresco” were intended? Theophilus, who promises to teach us all the Greeks knew in the art of paindng, would not, certainly, have neglected so important a branch.
